questions.text:
Arrange the following in the correct sequence of completion of events after transection of a nerve -
  1. Myelin sheath degeneration
  2. Chromatolytic reaction
  3. Regenerative sprouting
  4. Denervation hypersensitivity
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the correct sequence is 1-2-3-4 (option A)

Wallerian degeneration is a type of orthograde degeneration triggered by an injury to the axon. These changes occur from the point of injury in the neuron and move towards the nerve terminal, thereby interrupting the functional neural transmission. 

The sequence of changes that occur:

  • Myelin sheath degeneration distal to the injury.
  • Proximal axon degeneration (retrograde - from the axon to the cell body)
  • Chromatolysis reaction- Swelling of the cell body, eccentrically placed nucleus, and fragmentation of the rough endoplasmic reticulum
  • Regenerative sprouting - neurons regrow projecting multiple small, branches. 
  • Sometimes when a motor nerve is injured, there is a marked proliferation of the nicotinic receptors making them extremely sensitive. This is known as denervation hypersensitivity.

questions.text: During your internship, you observe a resident doctor examining the thyroid gland using the method shown in the video below. Identify the method.
questions.solution:
The above video shows Crile's method of thyroid palpation.

Crile's Method: The patient is asked to swallow while palpating the gland with the thumb. This method helps to identify mild enlargements and for detecting the presence of nodules.

Other options:

Option B: Lahey's Method: The lobes are pushed to one side for palpation. For palpating the left lobe, the examiner should push the lobe laterally with the left hand and the lobe is palpated with the right hand.

 

Option C: Kocher's method: It is done to demonstrate the pressure effect of the thyroid gland on the trachea or larynx. Lateral compression will result in stridor.

Option D: Pizillo's method: In short-necked and obese individuals the thyroid can be better inspected by asking the patient to place his hands behind the occiput of his/her head.

questions.solution:
The marked structure is the musculocutaneous nerve. Its root value is C5, C6, C7 and it arises from the lateral cord.
The structure can be identified as a musculocutaneous nerve as it pierces the coracobrachialis muscle in its course and also supplies the biceps brachii.

questions.text: Which of the circuits has the fresh gas inlet near the patient and corrugated tubing, but no reservoir bag?
questions.solution:
Ayre’s T piece, a type of Mapleson E system has the fresh gas inlet near the patient and corrugated tubing, but no reservoir bag.

Other Options:

Option A: Bain’s circuit or Mapleson D has the fresh gas inlet near the patient, a reservoir bag and corrugated tubing.

Option C: Water’s to and fro circuit or Mapleson C has the fresh gas inlet near the patient and a reservoir bag but no corrugated tubing.

Option D: Magill’s circuit or Mapleson A has the fresh gas inlet near the bag. It has a reservoir bag and corrugated tubing.

questions.text: A 51-year-old female patient, Mrs. Susheela presents to dermatology OPD with a rash as seen in the image below. On further inquiry, she reveals that she has unintentionally lost a lot of weight over the past few months. Medical history is significant for a recent diagnosis of type 2 diabetes mellitus for which she is being treated with T. Metformin 500mg. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image given depicts necrolytic migrating erythema. This along with the clinical presentation is strongly suggestive of a glucagonoma. 

Glucagonoma is a rare neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas, a majority of which are malignant at the time of presentation. They are most commonly seen arising from the pancreatic tail.

Clinically, the classic presentation of glucagonoma is with the “4 D’s”-

  • Diabetes
  • Dermatitis- A characteristic waxing and waning necrolytic migrating erythema is seen that usually appears before other symptoms.
  • Deep vein thrombosis 
  • Depression.

Diagnosis is established by estimating plasma glucagon levels. A level >1000 pg/mL is considered diagnostic (normal plasma glucagon level is <150 pg/mL). Hypoaminoacidemia is also a characteristic laboratory finding. 

Treatment may include long-acting somatostatin analogues like octreotide to alleviate some of the clinical symptoms such as dermatitis. Surgical resection may be attempted but is often unsuccessful due to extrapancreatic malignant spread at the time of diagnosis. 

Related Pearl: Pancreatic Endocrine Neoplasms

Endocrine neoplasm

Clinical features

Glucagonoma

Mild diabetes mellitus, a characteristic skin rash (necrolytic migratory erythema), and anemia

Insulinoma

Clinically significant hypoglycemia

Gastrinoma

Peptic ulceration often unresponsive to therapy and in unusual locations such as the jejunum

Somatostatinoma

Diabetes mellitus, cholelithiasis, steatorrhea, and hypochlorhydria

VIPoma

Watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, achlorhydria, or WDHA syndrome

Pancreatic polypeptide-secreting endocrine tumors

Present as mass lesions as even high plasma levels of this hormone fail to cause symptoms

Islet hyperplasia (previously known as nesidioblastosis) is seen in maternal diabetes, Beckwith–Wiedemann syndrome , and rare mutations in the β-cell K+-channel protein or sulfonylurea receptor.

In maternal diabetes, the fetal islets respond to hyperglycemia by increasing their size and number. In the postnatal period, these hyperactive islets may be responsible for serious episodes of hypoglycemia.

questions.text: There is a small school in a village, which has students from class 1-10. The classrooms are overcrowded and the area around the school is not clean. To ensure there is no breakout of tuberculosis, which of the following methods should the school adopt as primary prevention?

choices.text: Start ATT for those that are smear positive

questions.solution:
Reducing overcrowding in classrooms is a primary prevention method. Primary prevention is action taken prior to the onset of disease, which removes/reduces the possibility that a disease will ever occur. Ex: Improving standard of living, vaccination, etc.

Other Options:

Option A: Starting ATT for those that are smear-positive would be secondary prophylaxis 

Option C: Educating children is a primordial prevention method. It aims to prevent  development of risk factors.

Option D: Screening symptomatic children with Mantoux is a secondary prevention method.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female complains of lower backache. The radiographic image of her lumbosacral spine is given below. Which of the following tools can be used to compare the bone mineral density of this patient to the young normal reference level?
questions.solution:
The given case suggests osteoporosis and T-score are used to compare the bone mineral density of this patient to the young normal reference level.

The above image depicts the ballooning of disc spaces leading to the biconcave shape of the vertebral body known as ‘Codfish appearance’, classically seen in osteoporosis. 

It is caused due to the reduction in the strength of the bone that leads to an increased risk of fractures. WHO defines osteoporosis as a T-score less than -2.5. It is the gold standard to assess bone mineral density.

Other radiological features of osteoporosis:

  • Loss of vertical height of vertebra due to collapse
  • Ground glass appearance of bones especially in the bones like the pelvis
  • Loss of cortical bone (picture frame vertebrae) and trabecular bone (ghost vertebrae)
  • Loss of trabeculae in the proximal femur area.

Related Pearl: Z-score and T-score for osteoporosis:

Z-score:

It is the number of standard deviations a patient’s BMD(bone mass density) differs from the average BMD of their age, sex, and ethnicity.

A Z-score of -2 or below should trigger investigations for underlying disease.

T-score:

It is the BMD at the site when compared to the young normal reference mean. It is a comparison of a patient’s BMD to that of a healthy 30-year old.

  • Normal is a T-score of -1 or higher.
  • Osteopenia is defined as a T-score between -1.0 and -2.5.
  • Osteoporosis is defined as a T-score less than -2.5, that is a BMD which is two and a half standard deviations below the mean of a 30-year old man/woman.

questions.text: An infant seems normal at birth but develops breathing difficulties shortly after birth with feeding problems, vomiting, and hypotonia. His urine was found to have a characteristic smell of tomcat urine. Considering the most likely diagnosis, treatment of this child with ______ will result in a dramatic clinical and biochemical response?
questions.solution:
Tomcat urine odor is seen in Multiple carboxylase deficiency. Affected infants should be treated with Biotin.

Multiple carboxylase deficiencies lead to defects in the utilization of Biotin. In the neonatal form of the disease, clinically, the affected infants seem normal at birth, but develop breathing difficulties shortly after birth with feeding problems, vomiting, and hypotonia. If untreated, generalized erythematous rash, exfoliation, alopecia, failure to thrive, seizures, and even coma may occur. 

Treatment with Biotin (10 mg/day orally) usually results in an improvement in clinical manifestations and may normalize the biochemical abnormalities. Early diagnosis and treatment are critical to prevent irreversible neurologic damage. In some patients, however, complete resolution may not be achieved even with large doses (up to 80 mg/day) of biotin.

questions.text:
Match the following visual field defects with the likely site of the lesion -
  1. Right superior homonymous quadrantopia
  2. Right sided homonymous hemianopia
  3. Right homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing
  4. Right inferior quadrantic hemianopia
  5. Left-sided complete anopia
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1-C, 2-B, 3-E, 4-D, 5-A

Lesion site Fibers affected Visual defect
A - Lesion in left optic nerve Left nasal and left temporal fibers affected 5. Left-sided complete anopia
B - Lesion in left optic tract Left temporal and right nasal fibers affected 2. Right-sided homonymous hemianopia
C - Lesion in left Meyer's loop Left inferior temporal and right inferior nasal fibers affected

1. Right superior homonymous quadrantanopia (Pie in the sky) 
D - Lesion in left Baum's loop Left superior temporal and right superior nasal fibers affected 4. Right inferior homonymous quadrantanopia (Pie in the floor)
E - Lesion in left visual cortex sparing the macula Left temporal and right nasal fibers except the macular fibers 3. Right homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing

 

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text: A young woman presents with the following lesion on the right inguinal lymph node region. Direct microscopy of a smear from the lesion shows a school of fish appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario along with the image showing bubo formed from ruptured and necrosed right inguinal lymph node suggest the most likely diagnosis to be chancroid. 

Soft chancre or chancroid is caused by the gram-negative bacterium, Haemophilus ducreyi. 

It begins as inflammatory papules that undergoes central necrosis and forms multiple painful nonindurated ulcers with undermined edges. It is often associated with inguinal lymphad­enitis, which may suppurate and lead to bubo formation. They are usually unilateral, fluctuant and may rupture spontaneously to form inguinal ulcers and sinuses.

Autoinoculation from the primary ulcer may lead to multiple or kissing ulcers on opposing skin surfaces, as well as extragenital lesions.

Diagnosis:

  • Direct microscopy of smears from chancroid  - school of fish appearance of organisms
  • Culture of H. ducreyi from the lesion or from an aspirate of suppurative lymph nodes

The image below shows school of fish appearance of H. ducreyi on microscopy.

Treatment as per the NACO guideline:

  • Doxycycline 100mg orally twice daily for 21 days (to cover LGV) + azithromycin 1g orally single dose, OR 
  • Ciprofloxacin 500mg orally, twice a day for 3 days to cover chancroid
  • Partner notification and treatment
  • Fluctuant buboes should be aspirated through healthy skin

 

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presented with uncontrolled bleeding from the nose, that failed to settle with conservative methods. When examined, the bleeding point was difficult to localize. A transnasal endoscopic procedure was performed for artery ligation. An adjunctive procedure was performed in order to further control the epistaxis, with the incision shown in the image below. Which among the following arteries are exposed and ligated following this incision?
questions.solution:
The incision shown in the given image is the Lynch incision (external ethmoid incision), which exposes the anterior and posterior ethmoidal arteries. The anterior ethmoidal artery is often ligated as an adjunctive procedure to Transnasal Endoscopic Sphenopalatine Artery Ligation (TESPAL).

Spontaneous epistaxis in a hypertensive patient, >40 years of age which is difficult to localize is suggestive of posterior epistaxis.

  Anterior epistaxis Posterior epistaxis
Site Little's area or anterior part of the lateral wall Posterosuperior part of the nasal cavity, or difficult to localize
Age Children, young adults >40 years of age
Cause Usually trauma Spontaneous, due to hypertension or IHD
Bleeding Mild, easily controlled with conservative measures (pressure, anterior nasal pack) Severe requires hospitalization and posterior nasal pack

 

Management of Epistaxis:

  1. Pinching of the nose with thumb and index finger for about 5 min compresses the vessels of the Little’s area.
  2. Trotter’s method: The patient sits, leaning forward over a basin to spit any blood, and breathes quietly from the mouth. Cold compresses should be applied to the nose to cause reflex vasoconstriction.
  3. Cauterisation of the bleeding point- with silver nitrate or electrocautery. This is done under topical anesthesia.
  4. Anterior nasal packing
  5. Posterior nasal packing - Patients should be hospitalized.
  6. Endoscopic cauterization of the bleeding point. 
  7. Elevation of the mucoperichondrial flap and submucosal resection operation- for persistent and recurrent bleeds from the septum.
  8. Ligations of vessels:
    • External carotid artery.
    • Maxillary artery- Approached via Caldwell Luc operation.
    • Ethmoidal arteries- Approached via Lynch incision.
  9. Transnasal Endoscopic Sphenopalatine Artery Ligation (TESPAL)- Under topical anesthesia with sedation or under general anesthesia, the sphenopalatine artery (SPA) is localized and closed with a vascular clip as it exits the foramen. The anterior ethmoidal artery is often ligated by Lynch incision as an adjunctive procedure. It is effective in controlling posterior bleeds.
  10. Embolization of the maxillary arteries by an interventional radiologist, via femoral artery catheterization. Ethmoidal arteries cannot be embolized.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old G3P2L1 presents in labor at 30 weeks of gestation. She has a history of prior preterm labor. Which of the following are predictors for this condition?
  1. Cervical length on transvaginal ultrasound is 3.5 cm
  2. Bishop's score of 5
  3. Absence of fetal fibronectin
  4. Uterine contractions 3/hour 
  5. Presence of genital tract infection
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette suggests that the lady has gone into preterm labor. The predictors of this condition are 2 and 5 only. 

Preterm labor is defined as one where the labor starts before the 37th completed week (<259 days), counting from the first day of the last menstrual period.

Predictors of preterm labor:

  • Clinical predictors - 
    • History of prior preterm birth
    • Multiple pregnancies
    • Presence of genital tract infection
    • Symptoms of preterm labor
  • Biophysical predictors - 
    • Uterine contractions ≥4/hour
    • Bishop score ≥4
    • Cervical length on transvaginal ultrasound ≤2.5 cm
  • Biochemical predictors - 
    • Fetal fibronectin (fFN) in cervical/vaginal discharge >50 ng/mL
    • Increased levels of IL-6, IL-8, TNF-alpha

Related Pearl: Bishop’s Score (Modified)

Score 0 1 2 3
Dilatation (cm) Closed 1-2 3-4 5+
Cervical length (cm) >4 2-4 1-2 <1
Consistency Firm Medium Soft -
Position Posterior Midline Anterior -
Head-Station -3 -2 -1, 0 +1, +2

Total score = 13

Favourable= 6-13

Unfavourable= 0-5

Note: 

  • According to NICE guidelines, a score of 6-13 is favorable for induction of labour.
  • According to Williams Obstetrics (26th edition), a score of 9 or more indicates a high likelihood of successful induction.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman with a history of tuberculosis presents with increased weakness, fatigue, and edema. She complains of some shortness of breath on walking fast and performing any strenous physical activity. On examination, her neck veins are distended. ECG shows low voltage QRS complexes with diffuse flattening of T waves. Which of the following waveforms will be associated with this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
This patient's history and findings are suggestive of tuberculous constrictive pericarditis. The jugular venous pressure waveform seen in constrictive pericarditis is shown in the image 1.

Chronic constrictive pericarditis occurs as a result of resorption of chronic pericardial effusion and obliteration of the pericardial cavity by granulation tissue, which further forms a firm scar around the heart that may be calcified. In developing countries, the leading cause of chronic constrictive pericarditis is tuberculosis. Other causes include trauma, cardiac surgery, mediastinal irradiation, neoplastic disease, and relapsing infections.

In constrictive pericarditis, there is a diastolic dysfunction causing impaired ventricular filling due to limitations imposed by the thick, rigid pericardium. This reduced end-diastolic volume decreases the stroke volume causing fatigue, weakness, and exertional dyspnoea. The impaired ventricular filling also causes an increase in JVP as a result of the back-up of blood in the atria and the venous system (edema).

The waveforms seen in a normal JVP are:

  • a wave: corresponds to atrial contraction
  • c wave: tricuspid valve to bulge due to ventricular systole after the closure of valves 
  • x descent: corresponds to the atrial relaxation during atrial diastole
  • v wave: corresponds to the venous filling of the right atrium
  • y descent: passive emptying of the right atrium into the right ventricle

In constrictive pericarditis, there is a rapid 'x' and 'y' descent. The rapid 'y' descent is more prominent and reflects rapid early ventricular diastolic filling. This occurs due to the constricting pericardium, increasing the atrial pressures.

Image 2 shows abscence of 'a' waves. This is seen in atrial fibrillation.

 

Image 3 shows a giant 'a' wave which is seen in tricuspid stenosis due to forceful contraction of the atrium against a stenosed tricuspid valve. It is also seen in cases of right ventricular hypertrophy.

 

Image 4 shows cannon 'a' waves seen in AV conduction block, due to forceful atrial contraction against a closed tricuspid valve.

Giant 'v' wave is seen in tricuspid regurgitation.

Related Pearl: JVP waveform and the abnormalities

1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions
Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis
Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation

 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions
Absent x-descent Severe tricuspid regurgitation
Rapid x-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions
Dominant v-waves Tricuspid regurgitation

 

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

Abnormality Conditions
Prolonged y-descent Tricuspid stenosis
Rapid y-descent

Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation
Absent y-descent Cardiac tamponade

questions.text: A 61-year-old man presents with dementia and gait difficulties along with episodes of urinary incontinence. Physical examination is notable for magnetic gait. There is no papilledema. An MRI brain demonstrates ventricular enlargement. After a serial lumbar puncture, his gait significantly improves. Which of the following is the best management for this patient?
questions.solution:
The triad of dementia, ataxia, and urinary incontinence, along with the other clinical features and MRI showing enlarged ventricles, is highly suggestive of normal-pressure hydrocephalus. Ventriculo-peritoneal shunting is preferred in this condition.

Normal-pressure hydrocephalus is a reversible cause of dementia. It is caused by obstruction to the normal CSF flow in the cerebral convexity and delayed absorption into the venous system.

Clinical features of NPH triad:

  • ataxia (magnetic gait is described as slow and unsteady turns that are slow, broad-based, and short-stepped)
  • dementia
  • urinary incontinence

Papilloedema is not seen.

Diagnosis: 

  • Neuroimaging reveals enlarged lateral ventricles (hydrocephalus) with little or no cortical atrophy, although the sylvian fissures can be mistaken for perisylvian atrophy due to the propped open (so-called “boxcarring”) appearance.
  • CSF parameters are normal except for the high range of pressure.
  • Another confirmatory test performed is the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) tap test which shows marked improvement of symptoms with spinal fluid removal.

Treatment: Ventriculo-peritoneal shunting- It is done to drain excess cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). Complications of the shunting procedure include shunt obstruction, infection, intracerebral or intraventricular hemorrhage, malposition or breakage of the shunt, etc.

Other options: 

Idiopathic intracranial hypertension presents with transient vision loss, headache, and papilledema. Medical therapy includes acetazolamide and furosemide. Topiramate is also used due to carbonic anhydrase inhibitor activity. Surgical therapy includes optic nerve sheath decompression (or optic nerve sheath fenestration) and CSF shunting procedures.

questions.text: The barium enema of a 37-year-old male is as shown below. Which of the following condition is least likely to be the underlying cause?
questions.solution:
Apple core sign is least likely seen in pseudomembranous colitis among the given options.

The sign shown in the barium enema study is apple core sign/ napkin ring sign - Describes a short segment irregular circumferential stricture of the large bowel that has abrupt “shouldered” margins resembling an apple core. The appearance is classically described on contrast enema studies and is almost always due to a stenosing annular colon carcinoma. It is not seen in pseudomembranous colitis.

The appearance of the apple-core lesion of the colon also can be caused by other diseases :

  • Villous adenoma
  • Lymphoma with colonic involvement
  • Crohn's disease
  • Chronic ulcerative colitis
  • Ischaemic colitis
  • Chlamydia infection
  • Colonic tuberculosis
  • Helminthoma
  • Colonic amoebiasis
  • Colonic cytomegalovirus

Features seen in pseudomembranous colitis:

  • Bowel wall thickening
  • Thumbprinting
  • Accordion sign
  • Peritoneal free fluid

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents to the casualty after having overdosed on anti-hypertensive medication. On examination, there are multiple cuts on her wrists and history reveals multiple attempts at suicide. On further inquiry, her father reveals she has marked fluctuations in her mood with a history of unstable relationships. What is the major defense mechanism in patients with this personality disorder?
questions.solution:
The given history of repetitive self-destructive acts, unstable relationships, and mood swings point towards a diagnosis of borderline personality disorder. The main defense mechanism is splitting.

In splitting, external objects are divided into all good or all bad. Eg: The morning staff is perfect, the evening staff is terrible.

A borderline personality disorder is classified under Cluster B. It is characterized by an unstable effect, mood swings, marked impulsivity, unstable relationships, recurrent suicidal behavior, chronic feelings of emptiness or boredom, identity disturbance, and inappropriate anger. If stressed, individuals may become psychotic.

Other options :

Option A: Somatization: Psychic derivatives are converted into bodily symptoms.

Option B: Regression: Return to an earlier stage of development

Option D: Reaction formation: An unacceptable impulse is transformed into its opposite; results in the formation of character traits.

Related Pearl: Personality Disorders

Suspicious, distrustful, hypervigilant
Schizoid
Prefers to be loner, detached, unemotional

questions.text: A child was brought to your clinic with an erythematous rash on the cheek, which later spread downwards to involve his trunk and limbs. He has also had a low-grade fever, and mild upper respiratory tract infection for the past few days. The suspected organism contains:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and image are strongly suggestive of erythema infectiosum. The image is showing the classical slapped cheek appearance. It is caused by Parvoviruses. Parvovirus B19 is a non-enveloped single-stranded DNA virus. 

Clinically, parvovirus B-19 infection may have several presentations:

Erythema infectiosum- Also known as the fifth disease. The incubation period after infection is typically around 1-2 weeks. The hallmark of erythema infectiosum is the characteristic rash, which appears initially as erythematous facial flushing, often described as a “slapped cheek” appearance. Later, the rash spreads rapidly or concurrently to the trunk and proximal extremities as diffuse macular erythema. The child may be febrile. 

Transient aplastic crisis- It may be seen in patients with underlying chronic hemolytic anaemia like sickle-cell disease, thalassemia, hereditary spherocytosis, and RBC enzyme deficiencies like pyruvate kinase deficiency. Patients with aplastic crisis appear ill with fever, malaise, and paleness with tachycardia and tachypnea due to profound anaemia. The rash may or may not be present. 

Pure red cell aplasia- Persistent Parvovirus B19 infection in immunocompromised patients can cause chronic suppression of bone marrow and chronic anaemia, leading to pure red cell aplasia.

Maternal infection is associated with non-immune fetal hydrops and intrauterine fetal demise.

The diagnosis of erythema infectiosum is made clinically and does not require investigations routinely. Detection of viral DNA in the blood by PCR or nucleic acid hybridisation may be done for immunocompromised cases or prenatal diagnosis of infection.

It is self-limited and resolves on its own. IVIG may be given to immunocompromised children.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with developmental delay, short stature, a tendency to sunburn easily, and dry, scaly skin.  He has short and brittle hair and sparse eyebrows. Under polarized light microscopy of the hair strand, a pattern of alternating light and dark ‘tiger‐tail’ bands is seen.  What can be the  DNA repair defect in this case?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of trichothiodystrophy (TTD) which is caused by defective DNA Nucleotide Excision Repair (NER). Features like developmental delay, short stature, photosensitivity, and ichthyosis with short, brittle, and sparse hair are suggestive of the diagnosis. 

Trichothiodystrophy is an autosomal recessive disorder of DNA repair. Most patients carry mutations in the ERCC2 (XPD) gene of the nucleotide excision repair mechanism.

It is a multisystem disorder characterized by short, brittle, sulfur-deficient hair with a pattern of alternating light and dark ‘tiger‐tail’ bands under polarized light microscopy. Other features include photosensitivity, ichthyosis, developmental delay, and short stature.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old drowsy male was brought to the casualty. His pulse was 130/min, respiratory rate -30/min. His lab reports are given below. He showed improvement on nasogastric aspiration and administration of sodium bicarbonate, calcium gluconate, and 4-methyl pyrazole. What substance did he most likely consume?

ABG - metabolic acidosis

Total serum calcium - 6.8 mg/dL

Blood Urea – 100 mg/dl

Creatinine – 3.4 mg/dl

Urine analysis - Calcium oxalate crystals.
questions.solution:
The given scenario point towards ethylene glycol poisoning.

Ethylene glycol is converted to glyoxyaldehyde by alcohol dehydrogenase. Glyoxyaldehyde causes kidney damage. 

Methanol is converted to formaldehyde by alcohol dehydrogenase. Formaldehyde causes retinal damage like blurring of vision/loss of vision.

The principles of treatment for both these conditions are the same. It predominantly involves using fomipezole or ethanol to inhibit the metabolic conversion of these relatively non-toxic alcohols to their toxic metabolites.
